DOC.HEAD: Precede PANAMA CITY
Cheney Visits Troops in Panama
Eds: LEADS thruout with Cheney, Thurman quotes, ADDS byline, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived in Panama on Sunday to share Christmas dinner with U.S. troops and celebrate Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's decision to seek asylum. ``I am delighted that General Noriega has finally been run to ground,'' said Cheney after being told, as his plane approached Panama, that Noriega had sought political asylum at the Vatican Embassy. ``I think it is clear at this point that the Panamanian people have no use for him, that he has had to take sanctuary in a foreign embassy,'' said Cheney. He spoke to reporters shortly after his plane landed at Howard Air Force Base four miles west of Panama City. ``He no longer is a factor in Panama. Now it is up to the lawyers and the diplomats to figure out what is next,'' Cheney said. ``As far as I'm concerned, the military has done its job.'' Although there were 26,000 U.S. military personnel in Panama, there were none around the embassy when Noriega arrived there. An informed military source said Noriega, the ousted Panamanian strongman, drove himself or was driven to the embassy at about 3 p.m. and entered unaccompanied. Gen. Maxwell Thurman, chief of the U.S. Southern Command, said he ordered the embassy surrounded afterward because ``I have the security responsibility for all of Panama, so I don't want digbats (Dignity Battalions loyal to Noriega) blowing into the place. I would not want them to come with an armored car and blow their way into the embassy.'' ``I can imagine all the Vatican lawyers are going to be up at this hour,'' he added. It was unclear whether Noriega's decision will hasten the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Panama, said Col. Miguel Monteverde, a Pentagon spokesman. Military officials hoped Noriega's decision to seek asylum would ``take the spirit to resist'' out of scattered Noriega loyalists who were still fighting, Monteverde said. Cheney went to Panama to ``spend Christmas with troops in the field ... and of course to celebrate'' Noriega's surrender, Monteverde said. ``He is very interested in how they're doing, but I think he wants to show in a very real way that he appreciates their sacrifice in giving up Christmas and putting themselves in harm's way,'' Monteverde said. Cheney will return to Washington either Monday evening or Tuesday morning, Monteverde said. President Bush announced the surprise Cheney trip after a briefing at the Pentagon on Sunday, the fifth day of the U.S. invasion that drove Noriega from power.
